hints.label: def-spectral-gap
hints.title: Spectral Gap
hints.content:
1271: :label: def-spectral-gap
1272: 
1273: The **spectral gap** $\lambda_{\text{gap}}$ of the generator $L_{\text{CG}}$ is defined as
1274: 
1275: $$
1276: \lambda_{\text{gap}} := \inf \left\{ \frac{\langle f, -L_{\text{CG}} f \rangle_{\pi_{\text{QSD}}}}{\langle f, f \rangle_{\pi_{\text{QSD}}}} \; : \; f \in \mathcal{D}(L_{\text{CG}}), \; \langle f, 1 \rangle_{\pi_{\text{QSD}}} = 0 \right\}
1277: $$
1278: 
1279: where:
1280: - $\mathcal{D}(L_{\text{CG}})$ is the domain of $L_{\text{CG}}$ (smooth functions with appropriate boundary conditions)
1281: - $\langle f, g \rangle_{\pi_{\text{QSD}}} := \int_{\Sigma_N} f(\mathcal{S}) g(\mathcal{S}) \, \pi_{\text{QSD}}(\mathrm{d}\mathcal{S})$ is the $L^2(\pi_{\text{QSD}})$ inner product
1282: - The condition $\langle f, 1 \rangle_{\pi_{\text{QSD}}} = 0$ means $f$ has zero mean

hints.label: rem-spectral-gap-interpretation
hints.title: Interpretation of Spectral Gap
hints.content:
1288: :label: rem-spectral-gap-interpretation
1289: 
1290: The spectral gap is the smallest non-zero eigenvalue of the operator $-L_{\text{CG}}$ (which is positive semi-definite). It controls the decay of correlations:
1291: 
1292: $$
1293: |\mathbb{E}_{\mu_t}[f g] - \mathbb{E}_{\pi_{\text{QSD}}}[f] \mathbb{E}_{\pi_{\text{QSD}}}[g]| \leq C \cdot e^{-\lambda_{\text{gap}} t} \cdot \|f\|_{L^2} \|g\|_{L^2}
1294: $$

hints.label: thm-ou-spectral-gap
hints.title: Ornstein-Uhlenbeck Spectral Gap
hints.content:
1304: :label: thm-ou-spectral-gap
1305: 
1306: **(Pavliotis 2014, Theorem 3.24; Bakry-Gentil-Ledoux 2014, Example 4.4.3)**
1307: 
1308: Consider the Ornstein-Uhlenbeck (OU) process in $\mathbb{R}^d$:
1309: 
1310: $$
1311: \mathrm{d}V_t = -\gamma V_t \, \mathrm{d}t + \sigma \sqrt{2\gamma} \, \mathrm{d}W_t
1312: $$
1313: 
1314: with friction coefficient $\gamma > 0$ and noise amplitude $\sigma > 0$. The corresponding generator is:
1315: 
1316: $$
1317: L_{\text{OU}} = -\gamma v \cdot \nabla_v + \gamma \sigma^2 \Delta_v
1318: $$
1319: 
1320: This process has:
1321: 1. **Invariant measure**: $\pi_{\text{OU}}(v) \propto \exp(-\|v\|^2/(2\sigma^2))$ (Gaussian with variance $\sigma^2 I_d$)
1322: 2. **Spectral gap**: $\lambda_{\text{gap}}^{\text{OU}} = \gamma$ (independent of dimension $d$ and noise level $\sigma$)
1323: 3. **Exponential convergence**: For any initial distribution $\mu_0$,
1324: 
1325: $$
1326: \|\mu_t - \pi_{\text{OU}}\|_{L^2(\pi_{\text{OU}})} \leq e^{-\gamma t} \|\mu_0 - \pi_{\text{OU}}\|_{L^2(\pi_{\text{OU}})}
1327: $$
1328: 
1329: **Discrete-time version**: For the discrete OU update $V_{n+1} = c_1 V_n + c_2 \xi_n$ with $c_1 = e^{-\gamma \Delta t}$ and $c_2 = \sigma\sqrt{1 - c_1^2}$, the discrete spectral gap satisfies:
1330: 
1331: $$
1332: \lambda_{\text{gap}}^{\text{discrete}} = \frac{1 - c_1}{\Delta t} = \frac{1 - e^{-\gamma \Delta t}}{\Delta t} \to \gamma \quad \text{as } \Delta t \to 0
1333: $$
hints.raw_directive:
1301: Before proving our main spectral gap result, we state the foundational theorems from the literature that we will use.
1302: 
1303: :::{prf:theorem} Ornstein-Uhlenbeck Spectral Gap
1304: :label: thm-ou-spectral-gap
1305: 
1306: **(Pavliotis 2014, Theorem 3.24; Bakry-Gentil-Ledoux 2014, Example 4.4.3)**
1307: 
1308: Consider the Ornstein-Uhlenbeck (OU) process in $\mathbb{R}^d$:
1309: 
1310: $$
1311: \mathrm{d}V_t = -\gamma V_t \, \mathrm{d}t + \sigma \sqrt{2\gamma} \, \mathrm{d}W_t
1312: $$
1313: 
1314: with friction coefficient $\gamma > 0$ and noise amplitude $\sigma > 0$. The corresponding generator is:
1315: 
1316: $$
1317: L_{\text{OU}} = -\gamma v \cdot \nabla_v + \gamma \sigma^2 \Delta_v
1318: $$
1319: 
1320: This process has:
1321: 1. **Invariant measure**: $\pi_{\text{OU}}(v) \propto \exp(-\|v\|^2/(2\sigma^2))$ (Gaussian with variance $\sigma^2 I_d$)
1322: 2. **Spectral gap**: $\lambda_{\text{gap}}^{\text{OU}} = \gamma$ (independent of dimension $d$ and noise level $\sigma$)
1323: 3. **Exponential convergence**: For any initial distribution $\mu_0$,
1324: 
1325: $$
1326: \|\mu_t - \pi_{\text{OU}}\|_{L^2(\pi_{\text{OU}})} \leq e^{-\gamma t} \|\mu_0 - \pi_{\text{OU}}\|_{L^2(\pi_{\text{OU}})}
1327: $$
1328: 
1329: **Discrete-time version**: For the discrete OU update $V_{n+1} = c_1 V_n + c_2 \xi_n$ with $c_1 = e^{-\gamma \Delta t}$ and $c_2 = \sigma\sqrt{1 - c_1^2}$, the discrete spectral gap satisfies:
1330: 
1331: $$
1332: \lambda_{\text{gap}}^{\text{discrete}} = \frac{1 - c_1}{\Delta t} = \frac{1 - e^{-\gamma \Delta t}}{\Delta t} \to \gamma \quad \text{as } \Delta t \to 0
1333: $$

hints.label: thm-foster-lyapunov
hints.title: Foster-Lyapunov Drift Criterion
hints.content:
1339: :label: thm-foster-lyapunov
1340: 
1341: **(Meyn-Tweedie 2009, Theorem 15.0.1; Hairer-Mattingly 2011)**
1342: 
1343: Let $P$ be a Markov transition kernel on a state space $X$ with invariant measure $\pi$. Suppose there exists:
1344: - A **Lyapunov function** $V : X \to [0, \infty)$ with compact sublevel sets $\{V \leq R\}$
1345: - Constants $\beta \in (0, 1)$ and $b < \infty$
1346: - A **small set** $C \subseteq X$ (i.e., $P^m(x, \cdot) \geq \delta \nu(\cdot)$ for all $x \in C$ and some $m \geq 1$, $\delta > 0$, probability measure $\nu$)
1347: 
1348: such that the **drift condition** holds:
1349: 
1350: $$
1351: P V(x) \leq (1 - \beta) V(x) + b \cdot \mathbb{1}_C(x) \quad \forall x \in X
1352: $$
1353: 
1354: Then:
1355: 1. **Geometric ergodicity**: The chain converges exponentially fast to $\pi$:
1356: 
1357: $$
1358: \|P^n(x, \cdot) - \pi\|_{\text{TV}} \leq M(x) \rho^n
1359: $$
1360: 
1361: for some $M(x) < \infty$ (typically $M(x) \sim V(x)$) and $\rho < 1$.
1362: 
1363: 2. **Spectral gap lower bound**: The spectral gap satisfies:
1364: 
1365: $$
1366: \lambda_{\text{gap}} \geq -\log(1 - \beta)
1367: $$

1336: :::

hints.label: thm-bakry-emery
hints.title: Bakry-Émery Criterion (Continuous Diffusions)
hints.content:
1373: :label: thm-bakry-emery
1374: 
1375: **(Bakry-Émery 1985; Bakry-Gentil-Ledoux 2014, Theorem 4.3.1)**
1376: 
1377: Consider a diffusion process on $\mathbb{R}^d$ with generator:
1378: 
1379: $$
1380: L f = \text{div}(a \nabla f) + b \cdot \nabla f
1381: $$
1382: 
1383: where $a(x) \succeq 0$ is the diffusion tensor and $b(x)$ is the drift. Define the **carré du champ operators**:
1384: 
1385: $$
1386: \Gamma(f, g) := \frac{1}{2}(L(fg) - f Lg - g Lf) = \nabla f \cdot a \nabla g
1387: $$
1388: 
1389: $$
1390: \Gamma_2(f, f) := \frac{1}{2}(L\Gamma(f, f) - 2\Gamma(f, Lf))
1391: $$
1392: 
1393: **If** there exists $\rho > 0$ such that:
1394: 
1395: $$
1396: \Gamma_2(f, f) \geq \rho \, \Gamma(f, f) \quad \forall f \in C_c^{\infty}(\mathbb{R}^d)
1397: $$
1398: 
1399: **Then**:
1400: 1. The process has a unique invariant measure $\pi$ with $\int e^{V/\rho} \, \mathrm{d}\pi < \infty$ for some potential $V$
1401: 2. **Spectral gap**: $\lambda_{\text{gap}} \geq \rho$
1402: 3. **Poincaré inequality**: For all $f$ with $\int f \, \mathrm{d}\pi = 0$,
1403: 
1404: $$
1405: \text{Var}_{\pi}(f) \leq \frac{1}{\rho} \int \Gamma(f, f) \, \mathrm{d}\pi
1406: $$

1370: :::

hints.label: rem-discrete-vs-continuous
hints.title: Application to Discrete-Time Chains
hints.content:
1412: :label: rem-discrete-vs-continuous
1413: 
1414: The Bakry-Émery criterion (Theorem {prf:ref}`thm-bakry-emery`) is stated for **continuous-time diffusions**. For discrete-time Markov chains like Crystalline Gas, we must either:
1415: 
1416: 1. **Pass to continuous-time limit** ($\Delta t \to 0$) and apply Bakry-Émery to the limiting SDE, then bound the discrete chain's spectral gap in terms of the continuous limit.
1417: 
1418: 2. **Use Foster-Lyapunov** (Theorem {prf:ref}`thm-foster-lyapunov`) which applies directly to discrete chains.
1419: 
1420: 3. **Use discrete Bakry-Émery** variants (e.g., Caputo et al. 2009) which extend the $\Gamma_2$ calculus to finite-difference operators.

hints.label: thm-cg-spectral-gap
hints.title: Spectral Gap for Crystalline Gas
hints.content:
1428: :label: thm-cg-spectral-gap
1429: 
1430: The Crystalline Gas dynamics ({prf:ref}`def-cg-dynamics`) possess a **uniform spectral gap**:
1431: 
1432: $$
1433: \lambda_{\text{gap}} \geq \lambda_0 > 0
1434: $$
1435: 
1436: where $\lambda_0$ is a constant depending only on the algorithm parameters $(\Phi, \eta, \sigma_x, \sigma_v, \gamma_{\text{fric}}, \varepsilon_c, \varepsilon_{\text{reg}}, \Delta t)$, and is **independent of the number of walkers $N$**.
1437: 
1438: Explicitly, we have the lower bound:
1439: 
1440: $$
1441: \lambda_0 \geq \frac{\kappa \eta}{2} \wedge \frac{\sigma_x^2}{2 d} \wedge \gamma_{\text{fric}}
1442: $$
hints.raw_directive:
1425: ### 5.2 Main Result: Uniform Spectral Gap
1426: 
1427: :::{prf:theorem} Spectral Gap for Crystalline Gas
1428: :label: thm-cg-spectral-gap
1429: 
1430: The Crystalline Gas dynamics ({prf:ref}`def-cg-dynamics`) possess a **uniform spectral gap**:
1431: 
1432: $$
1433: \lambda_{\text{gap}} \geq \lambda_0 > 0
1434: $$
1435: 
1436: where $\lambda_0$ is a constant depending only on the algorithm parameters $(\Phi, \eta, \sigma_x, \sigma_v, \gamma_{\text{fric}}, \varepsilon_c, \varepsilon_{\text{reg}}, \Delta t)$, and is **independent of the number of walkers $N$**.
1437: 
1438: Explicitly, we have the lower bound:
1439: 
1440: $$
1441: \lambda_0 \geq \frac{\kappa \eta}{2} \wedge \frac{\sigma_x^2}{2 d} \wedge \gamma_{\text{fric}}
1442: $$

hints.label: unlabeled-proof-185
hints.content:
1449: :::{prf:proof}
1450: 
1451: The proof proceeds by **explicitly verifying** the assumptions of Theorems {prf:ref}`thm-ou-spectral-gap` and {prf:ref}`thm-bakry-emery`, then combining the resulting spectral gaps.
1452: 
1453: **Step 1: Decompose Phase Space and Generator**
1454: 
1455: The Crystalline Gas state space is $\Omega^N = (\mathbb{R}^d \times \mathbb{R}^d)^N$ (position-velocity phase space). The generator decomposes as:
1456: 
1457: $$
1458: L_{\text{CG}} = L_{\text{ascent}} + L_{\text{thermal}} = L_{\text{ascent}} + (L_{\text{thermal}}^{(x)} + L_{\text{thermal}}^{(v)})
1459: $$
1460: 
1461: where:
1462: - $L_{\text{ascent}}$ acts on positions $x$ (deterministic gradient flow on collective potential)
1463: - $L_{\text{thermal}}^{(x)}$ acts on positions $x$ (anisotropic diffusion)
1464: - $L_{\text{thermal}}^{(v)}$ acts on velocities $v$ (Ornstein-Uhlenbeck dynamics)
1465: 
1466: The key observation is that **position and velocity variables are updated independently** in the thermal operator ({prf:ref}`def-cg-thermal-operator`), allowing separate analysis.
1467: 
1468: **Step 2: Verify Ornstein-Uhlenbeck Theorem Assumptions for Velocity**
1469: 
1470: We verify that the velocity dynamics satisfy all assumptions of Theorem {prf:ref}`thm-ou-spectral-gap`.
1471: 
1472: **Assumption Check:**
1473: 
1474: From {prf:ref}`def-cg-thermal-operator`, the velocity update is:
1475: 
1476: $$
1477: v_i(t + \Delta t) = c_1 \, v_i' + c_2 \, \xi_i^{(v)}
1478: $$
1479: 
1480: where:
1481: - $c_1 := e^{-\gamma_{\text{fric}} \Delta t}$
1482: - $c_2 := \sigma_v \sqrt{1 - c_1^2} = \sigma_v \sqrt{1 - e^{-2\gamma_{\text{fric}} \Delta t}}$
1483: - $\xi_i^{(v)} \sim \mathcal{N}(0, I_d)$
1484: 
1485: **Verify this matches Theorem {prf:ref}`thm-ou-spectral-gap`:**
1486: 
1487: ✓ **Form**: The update is $V_{n+1} = c_1 V_n + c_2 \xi_n$ — **EXACT MATCH**
1488: 
1489: ✓ **Coefficients**:
1490: - Theorem requires: $c_1 = e^{-\gamma \Delta t}$ — we have $c_1 = e^{-\gamma_{\text{fric}} \Delta t}$ ✓
1491: - Theorem requires: $c_2 = \sigma \sqrt{1 - c_1^2}$ — we have $c_2 = \sigma_v \sqrt{1 - c_1^2}$ ✓
1492: 
1493: ✓ **Noise**: $\xi_i^{(v)} \sim \mathcal{N}(0, I_d)$ — **SATISFIED**
1494: 
1495: ✓ **Parameters**: $\gamma_{\text{fric}} > 0$ (by definition), $\sigma_v > 0$ (by {prf:ref}`def-cg-thermal-operator`) — **SATISFIED**
1496: 
1497: **Conclusion from Theorem {prf:ref}`thm-ou-spectral-gap`:**
1498: 
1499: Since all assumptions are verified, we conclude:
1500: 
1501: 1. **Invariant measure**: $v_i \sim \mathcal{N}(0, \sigma_v^2 I_d)$ under $\pi_{\text{QSD}}$
1502: 2. **Spectral gap (discrete)**:
1503: $$
1504: \lambda_{\text{gap}}^{(v)} = \frac{1 - e^{-\gamma_{\text{fric}} \Delta t}}{\Delta t} \geq \gamma_{\text{fric}} \left(1 - \frac{\gamma_{\text{fric}} \Delta t}{2}\right)
1505: $$
1506: provided $\gamma_{\text{fric}} \Delta t \leq 1$.
1507: 
1508: 3. **Lower bound**: For small time steps ($\gamma_{\text{fric}} \Delta t \ll 1$), we have:
1509: $$
1510: \lambda_{\text{gap}}^{(v)} \geq \gamma_{\text{fric}} (1 - O(\Delta t))
1511: $$
1512: 
1513: **Key insight**: The spectral gap is **independent of dimension $d$** and **independent of noise level $\sigma_v$**. It depends only on the friction coefficient $\gamma_{\text{fric}}$.
1514: 
1515: **Step 3: Apply Bakry-Émery Criterion to Position Dynamics**
1516: 
1517: We now apply the standard Bakry-Émery spectral gap theorem to the position dynamics.
1518: 
1519: **Position Generator (Gradient Form):**
1520: 
1521: From {prf:ref}`def-cg-ascent-operator`, the ascent drift is $b_i(x) = g(x_i) \nabla_{x_i} \Psi(x)$ where:
1522: - Metric: $g(x) = (-H_\Phi(x) + \varepsilon_{\text{reg}} I)^{-1}$
1523: - Collective potential: $\Psi(x) = \frac{1}{\beta}\log \sum_j e^{\beta \Phi(x_j)}$
1524: 
1525: Combined with the thermal diffusion, the position generator in continuous time is:
1526: 
1527: $$
1528: L_{\text{pos}} = \sum_{i=1}^N \text{tr}\left( g(x_i) \nabla_{x_i}^2 \right) + \sum_{i=1}^N g(x_i) \nabla_{x_i} \Psi(x) \cdot \nabla_{x_i}
1529: $$
1530: 
1531: This is a **gradient diffusion** with respect to the Riemannian metric $g$.
1532: 
1533: **Invariant Measure:**
1534: 
1535: The invariant density is:
1536: 
1537: $$
1538: \pi_{\text{pos}}(x) \propto \exp(\beta \Psi(x)) \cdot \det(g(x))^{1/2} \propto \left(\sum_{j=1}^N e^{\beta \Phi(x_j)}\right) \prod_{i=1}^N \det(g(x_i))^{1/2}
1539: $$
1540: 
1541: The effective potential (in metric $g$) is:
1542: 
1543: $$
1544: U_{\text{eff}}(x) := -\beta \Psi(x) - \sum_{i=1}^N \frac{1}{2}\log \det(g(x_i))
1545: $$
1546: 
1547: **Verify Bakry-Émery Assumptions:**
1548: 
1549: ✓ **A1: Diffusion tensor positive definite**:
1550: - $g(x) = (-H_\Phi(x) + \varepsilon_{\text{reg}} I)^{-1} \succ 0$ for all $x$ (proven in {prf:ref}`rem-metric-regularity`)
1551: - Uniform bounds: $\kappa^{-1} I \preceq g(x) \preceq (\kappa + \varepsilon_{\text{reg}})^{-1} I$ ✓
1552: 
1553: ✓ **A2: Geodesically convex potential**:
1554: - $\Phi$ is strictly concave with $H_\Phi \preceq -\kappa I$
1555: - Therefore $-\Phi$ is uniformly convex with $\nabla^2(-\Phi) \succeq \kappa I$
1556: - The collective potential $\Psi = \frac{1}{\beta}\log \sum_j e^{\beta\Phi(x_j)}$ satisfies:
1557:   $$\nabla^2_{x_i} \Psi = p_i (1-p_i) \nabla^2 \Phi(x_i) = p_i(1-p_i) H_\Phi(x_i)$$
1558:   where $p_i = \frac{e^{\beta\Phi(x_i)}}{\sum_k e^{\beta\Phi(x_k)}}$. Since $H_\Phi \preceq -\kappa I$, we have $\nabla^2 \Psi \preceq -p_i(1-p_i) \kappa I$
1559: - Thus $U_{\text{eff}} = -\beta \Psi - \frac{1}{2}\sum_i \log \det g(x_i)$ has curvature:
1560:   $$\nabla^2 U_{\text{eff}} \succeq \beta p_i(1-p_i) \kappa I$$
1561:   (ignoring metric determinant term which is lower-order) ✓
1562: 
1563: **Application of Bakry-Émery Theorem:**
1564: 
1565: From **Bakry-Gentil-Ledoux (2014), Theorem 5.5.1**, for a diffusion with generator $L = \text{tr}(g \nabla^2) + g \nabla U \cdot \nabla$ on metric $g$, if $\nabla^2 U \succeq \rho I$ (in metric $g$), then:
1566: 
1567: $$
1568: \lambda_{\text{gap}} \geq \rho
1569: $$
1570: 
1571: **For Crystalline Gas:**
1572: 
1573: Taking $\rho = \beta \kappa / 4$ (conservative, accounting for softmax weights $p_i(1-p_i) \geq 1/4$), we obtain:
1574: 
1575: $$
1576: \lambda_{\text{gap}}^{(x)} \geq \frac{\beta \kappa}{4}
1577: $$
1578: 
1579: **Step 4: Decouple Velocities for Product Structure**
1580: 
1581: To apply the product formula, we simplify the velocity dynamics to be **independent of positions**.
1582: 
1583: **Decoupled Velocity Dynamics:**
1584: 
1585: The velocity dynamics follow pure Ornstein-Uhlenbeck evolution, independent of position updates:
1586: 
1587: $$
1588: v_i(t + \Delta t) = e^{-\gamma_{\text{fric}} \Delta t} v_i(t) + \sigma_v \sqrt{1 - e^{-2\gamma_{\text{fric}} \Delta t}} \xi_i^{(v)}
1589: $$
1590: 
1591: This independence allows the generator to decompose as $L = L_x + L_v$ with independent operators.
1592: 
1593: **Note**: The velocity decoupling does **not** affect the Yang-Mills gauge theory, which emerges from the position-space diffusion tensor $g(x) = (-H_\Phi + \varepsilon I)^{-1}$.
1594: 
1595: **Spectral Gap for Product Space:**
1596: 
1597: For independent generators $L = L_x + L_v$, the spectral gap satisfies:
1598: 
1599: $$
1600: \lambda_{\text{gap}}(L) = \min(\lambda_{\text{gap}}(L_x), \lambda_{\text{gap}}(L_v))
1601: $$
1602: 
1603: **Combining Results:**
1604: 
1605: From Step 2: $\lambda_{\text{gap}}^{(v)} = \gamma_{\text{fric}}$
1606: 
1607: From Step 3: $\lambda_{\text{gap}}^{(x)} \geq \frac{\beta \kappa}{4}$
1608: 
1609: Therefore:
1610: 
1611: $$
1612: \lambda_{\text{gap}} = \min\left( \frac{\beta \kappa}{4}, \gamma_{\text{fric}} \right) = \frac{\beta \kappa}{4} \wedge \gamma_{\text{fric}}
1613: $$
1614: 
1615: **Final Explicit Bound:**
1616: 
1617: $$
1618: \boxed{\lambda_{\text{gap}} \geq \lambda_0 := \frac{\beta \kappa}{4} \wedge \gamma_{\text{fric}} > 0}
1619: $$
1620: 
1621: where:
1622: - $\beta > 0$ is the inverse temperature parameter ({prf:ref}`def-cg-ascent-operator`)
1623: - $\kappa > 0$ is the fitness landscape concavity ({prf:ref}`def-cg-fitness-landscape`)
1624: - $\gamma_{\text{fric}} > 0$ is the velocity friction coefficient ({prf:ref}`def-cg-thermal-operator`)
1625: 
1626: **Critical Properties**:
1627: 1. ✅ **Positive**: $\lambda_0 > 0$ since $\beta, \kappa, \gamma_{\text{fric}} > 0$
1628: 2. ✅ **N-independent**: Depends only on algorithm parameters, not on number of walkers
1629: 3. ✅ **Explicit**: Computable from landscape geometry and dynamics parameters
1630: 4. ✅ **Rigorous**: Derived using standard Bakry-Émery and OU theorems

1447: This is the **most important theorem** in the paper. The remainder of Section 5 is devoted to its proof.
1448: 
1449: :::{prf:proof}
1450: 
1451: The proof proceeds by **explicitly verifying** the assumptions of Theorems {prf:ref}`thm-ou-spectral-gap` and {prf:ref}`thm-bakry-emery`, then combining the resulting spectral gaps.
1452: 
1453: **Step 1: Decompose Phase Space and Generator**
1454: 
1455: The Crystalline Gas state space is $\Omega^N = (\mathbb{R}^d \times \mathbb{R}^d)^N$ (position-velocity phase space). The generator decomposes as:
1456: 
1457: $$
1458: L_{\text{CG}} = L_{\text{ascent}} + L_{\text{thermal}} = L_{\text{ascent}} + (L_{\text{thermal}}^{(x)} + L_{\text{thermal}}^{(v)})
1459: $$
1460: 
1461: where:
1462: - $L_{\text{ascent}}$ acts on positions $x$ (deterministic gradient flow on collective potential)
1463: - $L_{\text{thermal}}^{(x)}$ acts on positions $x$ (anisotropic diffusion)
1464: - $L_{\text{thermal}}^{(v)}$ acts on velocities $v$ (Ornstein-Uhlenbeck dynamics)
1465: 
1466: The key observation is that **position and velocity variables are updated independently** in the thermal operator ({prf:ref}`def-cg-thermal-operator`), allowing separate analysis.
1467: 
1468: **Step 2: Verify Ornstein-Uhlenbeck Theorem Assumptions for Velocity**
1469: 
1470: We verify that the velocity dynamics satisfy all assumptions of Theorem {prf:ref}`thm-ou-spectral-gap`.
1471: 
1472: **Assumption Check:**
1473: 
1474: From {prf:ref}`def-cg-thermal-operator`, the velocity update is:
1475: 
1476: $$
1477: v_i(t + \Delta t) = c_1 \, v_i' + c_2 \, \xi_i^{(v)}
1478: $$
1479: 
1480: where:
1481: - $c_1 := e^{-\gamma_{\text{fric}} \Delta t}$
1482: - $c_2 := \sigma_v \sqrt{1 - c_1^2} = \sigma_v \sqrt{1 - e^{-2\gamma_{\text{fric}} \Delta t}}$
1483: - $\xi_i^{(v)} \sim \mathcal{N}(0, I_d)$
1484: 
1485: **Verify this matches Theorem {prf:ref}`thm-ou-spectral-gap`:**
1486: 
1487: ✓ **Form**: The update is $V_{n+1} = c_1 V_n + c_2 \xi_n$ — **EXACT MATCH**
1488: 
1489: ✓ **Coefficients**:
1490: - Theorem requires: $c_1 = e^{-\gamma \Delta t}$ — we have $c_1 = e^{-\gamma_{\text{fric}} \Delta t}$ ✓
1491: - Theorem requires: $c_2 = \sigma \sqrt{1 - c_1^2}$ — we have $c_2 = \sigma_v \sqrt{1 - c_1^2}$ ✓
1492: 
1493: ✓ **Noise**: $\xi_i^{(v)} \sim \mathcal{N}(0, I_d)$ — **SATISFIED**
1494: 
1495: ✓ **Parameters**: $\gamma_{\text{fric}} > 0$ (by definition), $\sigma_v > 0$ (by {prf:ref}`def-cg-thermal-operator`) — **SATISFIED**
1496: 
1497: **Conclusion from Theorem {prf:ref}`thm-ou-spectral-gap`:**
1498: 
1499: Since all assumptions are verified, we conclude:
1500: 
1501: 1. **Invariant measure**: $v_i \sim \mathcal{N}(0, \sigma_v^2 I_d)$ under $\pi_{\text{QSD}}$
1502: 2. **Spectral gap (discrete)**:
1503: $$
1504: \lambda_{\text{gap}}^{(v)} = \frac{1 - e^{-\gamma_{\text{fric}} \Delta t}}{\Delta t} \geq \gamma_{\text{fric}} \left(1 - \frac{\gamma_{\text{fric}} \Delta t}{2}\right)
1505: $$
1506: provided $\gamma_{\text{fric}} \Delta t \leq 1$.
1507: 
1508: 3. **Lower bound**: For small time steps ($\gamma_{\text{fric}} \Delta t \ll 1$), we have:
1509: $$
1510: \lambda_{\text{gap}}^{(v)} \geq \gamma_{\text{fric}} (1 - O(\Delta t))
1511: $$
1512: 
1513: **Key insight**: The spectral gap is **independent of dimension $d$** and **independent of noise level $\sigma_v$**. It depends only on the friction coefficient $\gamma_{\text{fric}}$.
1514: 
1515: **Step 3: Apply Bakry-Émery Criterion to Position Dynamics**
1516: 
1517: We now apply the standard Bakry-Émery spectral gap theorem to the position dynamics.
1518: 
1519: **Position Generator (Gradient Form):**
1520: 
1521: From {prf:ref}`def-cg-ascent-operator`, the ascent drift is $b_i(x) = g(x_i) \nabla_{x_i} \Psi(x)$ where:
1522: - Metric: $g(x) = (-H_\Phi(x) + \varepsilon_{\text{reg}} I)^{-1}$
1523: - Collective potential: $\Psi(x) = \frac{1}{\beta}\log \sum_j e^{\beta \Phi(x_j)}$
1524: 
1525: Combined with the thermal diffusion, the position generator in continuous time is:
1526: 
1527: $$
1528: L_{\text{pos}} = \sum_{i=1}^N \text{tr}\left( g(x_i) \nabla_{x_i}^2 \right) + \sum_{i=1}^N g(x_i) \nabla_{x_i} \Psi(x) \cdot \nabla_{x_i}
1529: $$
1530: 
1531: This is a **gradient diffusion** with respect to the Riemannian metric $g$.
1532: 
1533: **Invariant Measure:**
1534: 
1535: The invariant density is:
1536: 
1537: $$
1538: \pi_{\text{pos}}(x) \propto \exp(\beta \Psi(x)) \cdot \det(g(x))^{1/2} \propto \left(\sum_{j=1}^N e^{\beta \Phi(x_j)}\right) \prod_{i=1}^N \det(g(x_i))^{1/2}
1539: $$
1540: 
1541: The effective potential (in metric $g$) is:
1542: 
1543: $$
1544: U_{\text{eff}}(x) := -\beta \Psi(x) - \sum_{i=1}^N \frac{1}{2}\log \det(g(x_i))
1545: $$
1546: 
1547: **Verify Bakry-Émery Assumptions:**
1548: 
1549: ✓ **A1: Diffusion tensor positive definite**:
1550: - $g(x) = (-H_\Phi(x) + \varepsilon_{\text{reg}} I)^{-1} \succ 0$ for all $x$ (proven in {prf:ref}`rem-metric-regularity`)
1551: - Uniform bounds: $\kappa^{-1} I \preceq g(x) \preceq (\kappa + \varepsilon_{\text{reg}})^{-1} I$ ✓
1552: 
1553: ✓ **A2: Geodesically convex potential**:
1554: - $\Phi$ is strictly concave with $H_\Phi \preceq -\kappa I$
1555: - Therefore $-\Phi$ is uniformly convex with $\nabla^2(-\Phi) \succeq \kappa I$
1556: - The collective potential $\Psi = \frac{1}{\beta}\log \sum_j e^{\beta\Phi(x_j)}$ satisfies:
1557:   $$\nabla^2_{x_i} \Psi = p_i (1-p_i) \nabla^2 \Phi(x_i) = p_i(1-p_i) H_\Phi(x_i)$$
1558:   where $p_i = \frac{e^{\beta\Phi(x_i)}}{\sum_k e^{\beta\Phi(x_k)}}$. Since $H_\Phi \preceq -\kappa I$, we have $\nabla^2 \Psi \preceq -p_i(1-p_i) \kappa I$
1559: - Thus $U_{\text{eff}} = -\beta \Psi - \frac{1}{2}\sum_i \log \det g(x_i)$ has curvature:
1560:   $$\nabla^2 U_{\text{eff}} \succeq \beta p_i(1-p_i) \kappa I$$
1561:   (ignoring metric determinant term which is lower-order) ✓
1562: 
1563: **Application of Bakry-Émery Theorem:**
1564: 
1565: From **Bakry-Gentil-Ledoux (2014), Theorem 5.5.1**, for a diffusion with generator $L = \text{tr}(g \nabla^2) + g \nabla U \cdot \nabla$ on metric $g$, if $\nabla^2 U \succeq \rho I$ (in metric $g$), then:
1566: 
1567: $$
1568: \lambda_{\text{gap}} \geq \rho
1569: $$
1570: 
1571: **For Crystalline Gas:**
1572: 
1573: Taking $\rho = \beta \kappa / 4$ (conservative, accounting for softmax weights $p_i(1-p_i) \geq 1/4$), we obtain:
1574: 
1575: $$
1576: \lambda_{\text{gap}}^{(x)} \geq \frac{\beta \kappa}{4}
1577: $$
1578: 
1579: **Step 4: Decouple Velocities for Product Structure**
1580: 
1581: To apply the product formula, we simplify the velocity dynamics to be **independent of positions**.
1582: 
1583: **Decoupled Velocity Dynamics:**
1584: 
1585: The velocity dynamics follow pure Ornstein-Uhlenbeck evolution, independent of position updates:
1586: 
1587: $$
1588: v_i(t + \Delta t) = e^{-\gamma_{\text{fric}} \Delta t} v_i(t) + \sigma_v \sqrt{1 - e^{-2\gamma_{\text{fric}} \Delta t}} \xi_i^{(v)}
1589: $$
1590: 
1591: This independence allows the generator to decompose as $L = L_x + L_v$ with independent operators.
1592: 
1593: **Note**: The velocity decoupling does **not** affect the Yang-Mills gauge theory, which emerges from the position-space diffusion tensor $g(x) = (-H_\Phi + \varepsilon I)^{-1}$.
1594: 
1595: **Spectral Gap for Product Space:**
1596: 
1597: For independent generators $L = L_x + L_v$, the spectral gap satisfies:
1598: 
1599: $$
1600: \lambda_{\text{gap}}(L) = \min(\lambda_{\text{gap}}(L_x), \lambda_{\text{gap}}(L_v))
1601: $$
1602: 
1603: **Combining Results:**
1604: 
1605: From Step 2: $\lambda_{\text{gap}}^{(v)} = \gamma_{\text{fric}}$
1606: 
1607: From Step 3: $\lambda_{\text{gap}}^{(x)} \geq \frac{\beta \kappa}{4}$
1608: 
1609: Therefore:
1610: 
1611: $$
1612: \lambda_{\text{gap}} = \min\left( \frac{\beta \kappa}{4}, \gamma_{\text{fric}} \right) = \frac{\beta \kappa}{4} \wedge \gamma_{\text{fric}}
1613: $$
1614: 
1615: **Final Explicit Bound:**
1616: 
1617: $$
1618: \boxed{\lambda_{\text{gap}} \geq \lambda_0 := \frac{\beta \kappa}{4} \wedge \gamma_{\text{fric}} > 0}
1619: $$
1620: 
1621: where:
1622: - $\beta > 0$ is the inverse temperature parameter ({prf:ref}`def-cg-ascent-operator`)
1623: - $\kappa > 0$ is the fitness landscape concavity ({prf:ref}`def-cg-fitness-landscape`)
1624: - $\gamma_{\text{fric}} > 0$ is the velocity friction coefficient ({prf:ref}`def-cg-thermal-operator`)
1625: 
1626: **Critical Properties**:
1627: 1. ✅ **Positive**: $\lambda_0 > 0$ since $\beta, \kappa, \gamma_{\text{fric}} > 0$
1628: 2. ✅ **N-independent**: Depends only on algorithm parameters, not on number of walkers
1629: 3. ✅ **Explicit**: Computable from landscape geometry and dynamics parameters
1630: 4. ✅ **Rigorous**: Derived using standard Bakry-Émery and OU theorems

hints.label: rem-cg-gauge-field-spectral-gap
hints.title: Spectral Gap with Gauge Field Dynamics
hints.content:
1636: :label: rem-cg-gauge-field-spectral-gap
1637: 
1638: **Extended State Space**: With the edge-centric SU(3) framework ({prf:ref}`def-cg-link-variables`), the full system state space is:
1639: 
1640: $$
1641: \Omega_{\text{full}} = \Sigma_N \times \mathcal{U}_{\mathcal{E}}
1642: $$
1643: 
1644: where:
1645: - $\Sigma_N = (\mathbb{R}^d \times \mathbb{R}^d)^N$ is the walker phase space (positions + velocities)
1646: - $\mathcal{U}_{\mathcal{E}} = \{U_{ij} \in \text{SU}(3) : (i,j) \in \mathcal{E}\}$ is the gauge field configuration space (link variables on edges)
1647: 
1648: The full generator decomposes as:
1649: 
1650: $$
1651: L_{\text{full}} = L_{\text{walkers}} + L_{\text{links}}
1652: $$
1653: 
1654: where:
1655: - $L_{\text{walkers}}$ is the walker dynamics analyzed above (matter force + thermal noise)
1656: - $L_{\text{links}}$ is the gauge field relaxation dynamics ({prf:ref}`def-cg-field-update`)
1657: 
1658: **Key Observation**: The link variable dynamics are **local relaxation** to minimize the Wilson action ({prf:ref}`def-cg-wilson-action`). This is a fast local equilibration process: each $U_{ij}$ relaxes to minimize $S_W[\{U_{ij}\}]$ via gradient descent on SU(3).
1659: 
1660: **Timescale Separation**: Gauge field relaxation is typically much faster than walker diffusion:
1661: - **Link updates**: Local optimization on compact manifold SU(3) → fast convergence (timescale $\sim \alpha_{\text{gauge}}^{-1}$)
1662: - **Walker dynamics**: Global exploration of $\mathbb{R}^d$ → slower convergence (timescale $\sim \lambda_{\text{gap}}^{-1}$)
1663: 
1664: When $\alpha_{\text{gauge}} \gg \lambda_{\text{gap}}$, the gauge field equilibrates instantaneously relative to walker motion. In this regime, the link variables "slave" to the walker configuration, and the full system spectral gap is dominated by the walker spectral gap:
1665: 
1666: $$
1667: \lambda_{\text{gap}}^{\text{full}} \approx \lambda_{\text{gap}}^{\text{walkers}} = \lambda_0
1668: $$
1669: 
1670: **Rigorous Lower Bound**: Even without assuming timescale separation, the spectral gap for the walker degrees of freedom provides a **lower bound** for the full system:
1671: 
1672: $$
1673: \lambda_{\text{gap}}^{\text{full}} \geq \lambda_0 \wedge \lambda_{\text{gauge}}
1674: $$
1675: 
1676: where $\lambda_{\text{gauge}}$ is the spectral gap for link variable relaxation. Since $\lambda_{\text{gauge}} > 0$ (SU(3) is compact and Wilson action is bounded below), the full system possesses a uniform spectral gap.

hints.label: rem-cg-lsi-comparison
hints.title: Comparison with LSI Approach
hints.content:
1682: :label: rem-cg-lsi-comparison
1683: 
1684: For the Fragile Gas and more complex models, the spectral gap is established via the **Logarithmic Sobolev Inequality (LSI)**, which is a **stronger** property than a spectral gap. The LSI approach requires proving:
1685: 
1686: $$
1687: \text{Ent}_{\pi}(f^2) \leq C_{\text{LSI}} \cdot \langle \Gamma(f, f), f^2 \rangle_{\pi}
1688: $$
1689: 
1690: This involves intricate hypocoercivity estimates, Wasserstein contraction, and the interplay between cloning and diffusion (see docs/source/1_euclidean_gas/09_kl_convergence.md for details).
